contentrichtext.text: '{{Notability|date=February 2013}} ''Barré Studio''' was, in all probability, the first film studio dedicated to animation (the rival for this honor is [[Bray Productions]]). It was founded by [[Raoul Barré]] and [[Bill Nolan (animator)|William Nolan]] in 1914. They began with advertising films (among the first animated films used to sell something), then got a series with [[Thomas Edison|Edison]] called the ''Animated Grouch Chaser''. The series was mostly live-action with a few animated inserts, not really all that bad in quality for the time they were made. The studio also put out the ''Phables'' and ''The Boob Weekly'' cartoons. Animators included [[Frank Moser (artist)|Frank Moser]], [[Gregory La Cava]], [[George Stallings (animator)|George Stallings]], Tom Norton and [[Pat Sullivan (film producer)|Pat Sullivan]], all of whom got their starts here. [[Rube Goldberg]] was the writer for ''The Boob Weekly''. In 1916, [[William Randolph Hearst]] founded [[International Film Service]], and hired all of Barré's animators to work for him, including Bill Nolan. Soon afterward, Barré was contacted by [[Charles Bowers]], who had been animating ''[[Mutt and Jeff (comic strip)|Mutt and Jeff]]'' for a year. The series was doing so well that it had outgrown Bowers' studio. A partnership was formed: Bowers' animators and series worked on in Barré's studio. The result was the Bud Fisher Film Corporation, named for the originator [[Bud Fisher]] of the ''Mutt and Jeff'' comic strip. It was known in the industry as the '''Barré-Bowers Studio'''. Fisher took all public credit for the cartoons, while Barré supervised the animators and Bowers handled the books. He "handled" the books so well, in fact, that he ruined the company: Barré quit in 1918 to avoid getting charged as an accomplice; Bowers was fired in 1919 ''and'' 1921. Once Fisher was in charge, he proved his financial abilities by completely bankrupting Barré-Bowers in 1923. (C Revelation Films) Besides Barré and Bowers, directors at their studio included [[Manny Gould]] and Dick Friel. Animators included C. T. Anderson, Clarence Rigby, George Stallings, [[Ted Sears]], [[Mannie Davis]], [[Burt Gillett]], [[Dick Huemer]], [[Ben Sharpsteen]], [[Bill Tytla]], [[Albert Hurter]], Carl Lederer, F. M. Follett, [[Isadore Klein]], Milt Gross, [[Walter Lantz]] and George Ruffle. == Filmography == '''Series''' *Animated Grouch Chasers (1915) *The Boob Weekly (1916) *Mutt and Jeff (1913-1926). '''One-Shots''' *Cartoons On A Yacht (1915). == References == * [[Denis Gifford]]; ''American Animated Films: The Silent Era, 1897-1929''; McFarland & Company; ISBN 0-89950-460-4 (library binding, 1990) {{DEFAULTSORT:Barre Studio}} [[Category:American animation studios]] [[Category:Companies established in 1914]] [[Category:Defunct companies of the United States]] {{animation-studio-stub}}
